list_definition.definition: a ski race down a winding course marked by flags; a similar race for canoes in water

list_ex_of_english: In 1962, he became double world student champion in alpine skiing's slalom and alpine combined event.
The aim is to maneuver a skier through a downhill ski course, a slalom course, and a ski jumping competition in the shortest time possible.
The straighter sidecut allows skis to make long, fast, highly stable turns (radius around 30m for giant slalom, even more for most mogul skis).
In the slalom, he coincided with his brother in eighth place in the giant slalom and in eleventh.
He won a gold medal in the giant slalom with a combined run time of 2:03.15, 0.43 seconds faster than the silver medallists.
Up to six players compete individually on either a downhill or slalom course to see who can complete the course the fastest.
Among the most popular are ice hockey, football, tennis, handball, basketball, volleyball, whitewater slalom or athletics.
Figure 6 shows a slalom maneuver steered by a human driver trying to avoid three obstacles.
